Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrated Approach to Magnetic Resonance Imaging Using Massive Arrays

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The long-term goal of this CAREER proposal is to develop next generation signal processing algorithms and to produce manpower to realize the full potential of massive arrays for high-speed and high-field MRI. Specifically, novel RF pulse design methods and image reconstruction algorithms will be developed and integrated with an existing advanced array system and computing environment to enable ultrafast imaging at a high-field strength (4.7 Tesla). This project will be built upon the preliminary work by the PI in large-array parallel imaging at one of the world?s leading laboratories in this field. In addition, multidisciplinary collaborations with academic, industrial, and clinical experts have been formed to provide resources to support this research. To maximize the productivity and benefits of the research and related discoveries, this project will educate undergraduate and graduate students for MRI research through an innovative ?Peer Instruction? method and exchange program with collaborators? labs. Furthermore, it will promote MR engineering research among a diverse group of students through collaboration with an NIH/NSF-supported K-12 outreach program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a premier noninvasive medical imaging method. However, MRI is less sensitive than positron emission tomography (PET), and is still a relatively slow modality when compared to ultrasound, X-ray computer tomography (CT), and optical imaging. Recent developments in large array systems and high field technology enable the engineers and scientists to advance the capability of the MRI systems to make better and faster diagnosis. Large array systems can transmit or receive radiofrequency (RF) signals through a large number of parallel channels and thereby improve performance over single-channel systems. With a state-of-the-art scanner, a 128-channel receive array system has the potential to generate a data flow of up to 1.5 Giga Byte per minute. The research and development supported by this award aim to design sophisticated and dedicated algorithms to optimally utilize such systems to advance MRI beyond current technical limits, for example, to perform MRI at extremely high imaging speeds and/or at high field strengths while limiting RF power deposition and peripheral nerve stimulation. The results of our work have led to 1) a new pulse design algorithm to improve efficiency and the RF safety for parallel excitation with large arrays; 2) three advanced reconstruction algorithms for parallel MRI with massive arrays; 3) a fast compressive sensing MRI reconstruction method using parallel computing; and 4) advanced method to analyze flow field with MRI, a common application require fast imaging. This NSF support has also contributed to human resource development in biomedical science and engineering, including training of 6 graduate students (3 females) and 8 undergraduate students in honor/summer research program. One of the female students, served as a senior engineer at GE Healthcare and then a research scientist at Univ. of California. Another student from the group becomes a tenure-track faculty. One undergraduate student won 2nd place prize for honor undergraduate research award. The research results from this work will help making real-time pulse design and image reconstruction for large arrays in MRI therefore help moving these technologies from lab development to clinical applications.
